titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Elmer J. Holland Papers, 1937-1968 AIS.1968.23
titlestmt.author: Allyson Glazier.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-08 17:13:51 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Elmer J. Holland Papers document the career of Holland, a member of the U.S. House of Representatives in 1942-1943 and 1956-1968. The collection includes a personal file of correspondence, memoranda, speeches, and statements, a legislative file of bills introduced, committee assignments, and constituent correspondence files relating to the armed services, immigration, post office, service academies, and veteran affairs. The collection also contains special files on local communities which include the correspondence, reports, and research data on those communities, as well as subject files of reference material used in researching background information.

physloc.emph: Due to the size and location of this collection, researchers are required to notify the Archives Service Center at least 24 hours in advance for use of this collection.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Elmer J. Holland was born in Pittsburgh, Pa., on January 8, 1894, the son of Thomas and Margaret (Keelan) Holland. He was educated in the Pittsburgh Public Schools, Duquesne University, and the University of Montpelier, France, and a graduate of the Civil Affairs School (United States Army), University of Pittsburgh, and the American School Center in Shriverham, England. He served in World War I in the American Expeditionary Forces and graduated from Saumur Artillery School, France, as lieutenant in the Field Artillery. He also served in World War II as a major in the Allied Military Government in European Theater of Operations; past commander, Post 435, Veterans of Foreign Wars; member of the American Legion. He was married to the former Emily J. Wilson, of Pittsburgh and had two daughters, Janie and Christin.

Holland was a member of the Pennsylvania General Assembly in the House of Representatives (1934-1942) and served as the superintendent of highways and sewers in Pittsburgh, Pa., during part of this time (1940-1942). Holland was elected as a Democrat to the 77th U.S. House of Representatives to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Joseph A. McArdle; he served from May 19, 1942, to January 3, 1943, and was not a candidate for renomination in 1942. He served as a member of the Pennsylvania State Senate (1943-1956) and then was elected to the 84th U.S. Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Representative Vera Buchanan. He was reelected to the 85th and the five succeeding Congresses, serving from January 24, 1956 until his death in Annapolis, Md., on August 9, 1968. He is buried in the Arlington National Cemetery.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Archives Service Center staff.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Elmer J. Holland Papers, 1937-1968, AIS.1968.23, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Elmer J. Holland Papers, 1937-1968, AIS.1968.23, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Series III, Constituent Correspondence Files, Subseries 1-8 (Boxes 115-195) regarding individuals, the Armed Services, immigration, Positions, Post Office, Service Academies, Veterans, and Social Security) have been closed for research for 75 years after the date of the creation of the record. With exception of the constituent correspondence files, which remain closed at this time, the files are open to qualified scholars and students for research and study.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Elmer J. Holland on December 31, 1968.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Elmer J. Holland Papers are arranged in the following nine series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Elmer J. Holland Papers contains correspondence, memorabilia, documents, speeches and statements, reports, news releases, a legislative file containing committee assignments and activities, constituent correspondence files relating to the armed services, immigration, post office, service academies, and veteran affairs; also included are special files on local communities which include the correspondence, reports, and research data on those communities, as well as subject files of reference material used in researching background information.

Boxes numbered 64-114 contained copies of the Congressional Record which were indexed by Congressman Holland's staff. These print copies were deaccessioned since the publication exists in microform. The user must consult the micro text edition held in the microforms area of the Hillman Library.

Labor
Transportation
Politicians -- United States
Politicians -- Pennsylvania
controlaccess.corpname: Pennsylvania. General Assembly. House of Representatives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Personal File contains Elmer J. Holland's correspondence during his political career between the years of 1942 and 1968. It also includes memoranda and voting records 1958-1967, speeches and statements 1937-1967, and other correspondence between 1957-1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence subseries contains Elmer J. Holland's correspondence during his political career between the years of 1942 and 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Special Subseries contains memoranda, letters, invitations, photographs and voting records 1958-1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Statements Subseries contains Elmer J. Holland's speeches and statements between 1937 and 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Subject Subseries contains Elmer J. Holland's correspondence between 1957 and 1968 relating to city and county positions, contributions, and the Democratic National and State Committee.

did.unittitle: Correspondence Relating to City and County Positions
Correspondence Relating to City and County Positions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Legislative File contains legislation introduced by Elmer J. Holland 1956-1968, information regarding the committees on which he served, and his remarks in the Congressional Record.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Legislation Introduced Subseries contains legislation and notes introduced by Elmer J. Holland 1956-1968.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Series II: Legislative File Subseries C. Congressional Records contained copies of the Congressional Record which were indexed by Congressman Holland's staff. These print copies were deaccessioned since the publication exists in microform. The user must consult the micro text edition held in the microforms area of the Hillman Library. A list prepared from the index headings compiled by the congressman's staff can be found in the collection's case file at the Archives Service Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Congressional Record Subseries contains Elmer J. Holland's remarks on the Congressional Record.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Series 3, Constituent Correspondence Files, Sub series A-H have been closed for research for 75 years after the date of the creation of the record. These files deal with armed services, immigration, positions, post office, service academies, veterans, and social security correspondence from Holland's constituents.

Mrs. Holland, in giving the records to the Archives, requested that this portion of the file be closed for ten years; however, because of the confidential nature of the material the file will remain closed for 75 years after the date of the creation of the record.
No access is permitted until that time unless the problem has been reviewed and a new determination made.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Constituent Correspondence Files contain letters to/from constituents relating to the armed services, immigration, post office, service academies, and veteran affairs.
